title: CTRL0000915973 - Transcribed Interview of Jacqueline Shay Kotkiewicz, (June 2, 2022)

data.text: JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL,
The interview in the above matter was held via Webex, commencing at 1:13 p.m.
For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE
THE JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL:
This is the transcribed interview of Jacqueline Kotkiewicz
conducted by the House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack on the
U.S. Capitol pursuant to House Resolution 503.
At this time, I'd ask the witness to please state your full name, and spell your last
Now, this will be a staff-led interview, although members
I will note that there are no members currently present.
and I'm investigative counsel with the
And with me from the select committee is
And also joined with us electronically is
At this time, I'd ask counsel to identify himself for the record.
Stefan Passantino, P, as in Paul, a-s-s, as in Sam,
Now, Ms. Kotkiewicz, you are voluntarily here for this
transcribing the record of this interview.
not audio or video record the proceeding.
The ground rules for this interview are there's an official reporter
The reported transcription is the official record
This proceeding is also audio and video recorded.
Please wait until each question is completed before you begin to respond, and I'll
do my best to wait until your response is complete before I ask the next question.
reporter cannot note nonverbal responses, such as shaking or nodding your head, so it's
important that you respond to each question with an audible, verbal response.
Please give complete answers to the best of your recollection.
Also, to remind you that it's unlawful to deliberately provide false information to
Congress, and doing so could result in criminal penalties under the law.
If you do not know the answer, please just say so.
Logistically, if at any time you need a break or to speak privately with your lawyer,
And do you have any questions before we begin?
Can you provide us with your full name?
And how do you spell your middle name?
And what's your date of birth?
And what's your cell phone number?
Is that the number you had in November and December of 2020?
Do you have an lnstagram account or a Twitter account?
And what are your handles for each one?
And I believe my lnstagram account is the same.
And did you have those in December of 2020 and November 2020?
Now, I want to go to your educational background.
Can you tell us a bit
Graduated with a double major in political science and public policy, and minored in
And what year did you graduate?
And then I attended Gettysburg College in Gettysburg, Pennsylvania.
So I want to turn to your job for President J. Trump's
Is your Linkedln public account, is that, as far as you know, accurate as to your
I graduated from Central Dauphin High School in Harrisburg,
for Inc. -- Donald J. Trump for President, Inc., the Trump Campaign.
Is it accurate that you started working for the Trump Campaign in
September of 2019 as a research analyst?
Can you tell us a bit about your role for the Trump Campaign as a research
I want to start first with the preelection period.
I mean, that's pretty broad, I would say.
Originally, when there were multiple candidates, I was in charge of the Elizabeth
Warren book, building out opposition research on Elizabeth Warren.
Biden became the nominee, all of us together turned towards Joe Biden.
specifically in charge of the energy and the environment chapters, as well as the
education chapter and the social issues chapters of the Joe Biden opposition book that
And then the other half the time, we would be monitoring when Joe Biden had
live events, whether that was town halls or if he was doing a debate, and we would be
fact-checking him in real time or we would be flagging clips for the war room to clip.
We'd also monitor Sunday shows, if there were any good clips from other Democrat
candidates that we could push around on Twitter.
basically of what my job was.
Let's talk about the reporting structure.
Let's do for the period of 2020.
Who did you report to as a
So if it changed over 2020, let me know.
But from January 2020 forward, who did you report to?
both Dean Cleary and Zach Parkinson.
And I think that was the general basis
At one point, Dean Cleary, he was a research analyst
He became promoted to our deputy research director.
And who were the other research analysts with you in 2020?
let's start with the preelection period, and to the extent that changed post-election, then
There was myself, a girl named Kiersten
Pels, Luis Cornelio, I believe, Brent Perrin, Dean Cleary, and then David Brown.
And then after the election, it was just myself, Matt VanHyfte, and Dean
that were asked to stay on longer.
And when -- was that from election day forward, or at what point did that
I think it was November 15th, if I remember correctly, but I'm not positive.
So from election day, November 3rd, to November 15th, was the research
team still as -- the same general folks you mentioned earlier?
Who did you understand Zach Parkinson to report to?
I believe he reported to Tim Murtaugh.
And that's the communications director, correct?
So is it fair to say the research team sat within the com ms department?
Originally, we sat in the war room, which was right outside of
Later, we kind of got pushed down to a different part of the
office, so we were closer to the strategic communications area but all within com ms.
And when you say the office, what are you referencing?
I don't remember the address, but it's in Arlington, on the 14th floor.
Now, preelection, did there come a time where you were
asked -- you were asked to research anything related to fraud or voting irregularities
Are you aware of anyone else being asked to do any research related to
fraud claims or anything of the like?
Before the election, did you do any research regarding fund raising emails or
As to the accuracy of statements made there within or anything of the like.
So a fund raising -- we understand -- just to give you background, and let me know
We understand that Zach Parkinson reviewed fundraising
emails and texts during some of his -- as part of some of his responsibilities as research
First, were you aware of that, that he had that role?
And did any work related to that effort come down to you or any research
analysts as far as you know?
of generic texts about going out to vote, making sure, you know, for the pre-voting period
where you can go and vote early, getting people to request absentee ballots if they're
eligible, just giving, like, voting information, general, like, texts and emails having to do
the RNC, just generic fundraising and texts.
It was -- I would say it was an almost daily email we would get from
Sometimes it was more than once a day, and it would be just a bunch
It's kind of all over the place.
Like, I still do that now in my current role at
Now, when you say you get this email, who is the we?
Zach would pass it to the research team.
He would just send it, and then
one of us would go through -- we'd comb through it for edits, to make sure things were
accurate and also like a grammar check.
Now, when you say things were accurate, can you explain to me what kind of
I mostly just kept an eye out for statistics.
So I guess this like -- for
instance, gas prices, making sure they're using the correct gas price number, like statistics
So is it fair to say that you were looking for things that could be proven
Would you ever look -- I'm going to use the term, like, a political
So someone says, Joe Biden would be the worst President ever.
say that that's not the kind of statement you would research as to truth and accuracy?
Now, as far as preelection, the review of fundraising emails and
texts, was it just you reviewing that for the analysts or was this sent to all the analysts?
It was sent to -- I believe, I don't exactly remember, but I believe it was sent
to all the analysts, and we would just take turns every day, because they were quite
lengthy, so one of us a day would kind of go through it.
And then when someone had gone through it -- so let's say you went
through it, would you -- was the email going to Zach Parkinson first who would then
forward it or were you directly receiving the emails from the digital folks?
It would go to Zach Parkinson because, ultimately, he was responsible
So he would do a second review, and then he would on his own send edits
So it would go to Zach.
He would forward it to the analysts, and
then the analysts would internally know who's turn it was to do the review?
Do you have any recollection of seeing any post-election fundraising emails
Do you recall having any discussions with any other analysts or Zach
I do not believe so, but I do not remember.
Parkinson or anyone else in the com ms department regarding fundraising emails or texts?
Were you ever asked to do any research in regards to fund raising emails that
had to do with discussions of a stolen election or election fraud?
Did any of your work ever involve researching, preelection, the President's
Did that involve researching the President's statements regarding the
potential for election fraud or any election fraud related claims?
I don't recall, but I don't believe so.
What kind of statements of the President would you -- and to be clear, I
mean President Trump when I'm asking these as the President at that time.
What kind of statements of his would the research team research?
It would mostly just be fact checks.
Trump said it killed a lot of birds, and then we would have to do research too, because
Politi Fact or The Washington Post would contact us.
some type of basis to back up President Trump's statements.
This is a silly example, but for the wind power, like, President
So we had to provide evidence or
I want to move forward in 2020, closer to election day.
week -- let's talk about the week or the days leading into election day, around that time.
The research team, did you all have any preparation for either work that had to do
with election day or the expected work post-election day?
election day, were you all preparing for anything?
We were preparing for election day itself.
after election day, I would say.
not on the research side of things, not myself, no.
So I'm talking about, prior to
We were not really preparing for
We had like a legal team, but
And what were the preparations the research team was doing for election
They were just looking for extra bodies as a
backup war room in case something happened with the WiFi, with the actual war room,
where we would just get calls and pass along information and fun tidbits about election
So I just went to a meeting about that.
Other than that, that was our only
And when you say the war room, what did the war room do?
On election day, I actually don't know because I didn't get to be part of it,
because they didn't need a backup war room.
What was your understanding, if you were needed, what you would've been
I would've been in contact with someone on the ground in one of the States.
They would have had to report to me, I think it was every 10, 15, 30 minutes, not sure on
the exact timing, but with what they knew about the vote counts or turnout or things like
I'm not exactly sure because I never had to do it.
So let's move forward to election day, November 3rd, 2020.
I was in the Trump Campaign headquarters on the 14th floor.
And so the results are coming in that evening.
Is it like a big group watch?
Yes, but we're at our desks.
We were sitting on our computers.
We weren't like partying or drinking anything.
But I sat in the bullpen, so I was with everyone.
So let's go -- the results are going in.
thinking about the state of the election around that time.
Let's go later in the evening,
So, you know, States have come in and whatnot.
So prior to President Trump making his statements that he made, tell us about
your personal take on what the results of the election were.
I'm with everyone in the office.
Are you just observing the results?
I honestly didn't know at that time.
No one knew really what the final
Do you remember President Trump speaking early that day, I think at like
I was awake, but I don't really remember.
Did you do any work related to the research team on election day?
So is it fair to say that you didn't work election day, like, as far as you can
I'm sure we had some type of project to do.
I don't think we had a lot of work to do on election day.
day with absolutely nothing to do.
or something silly, but I don't know.
I don't think we were sitting all
But it might have just been making like a Twitter list
Let's kind of walk through that week.
Tell me about what kind of -- progress us through as much as you can recall what
I actually have a very difficult time remembering because we didn't go to
bed till 3 or 4 a.m., like, election night.
think we were trying to do some opposition research on the FOX News person who called
Arizona to, like, show he had Democrat -- like, leaning Democrat bias.
believe it was next day we -- might have been a few days after.
timeline specifically -- the Trump war room hotline started, so I was helping take calls and
We were back in office early the next day.
So we'll talk about the dead voter project in a minute, but let's start with the
Who asked you to join with that?
And tell us about the project.
And then when I wasn't doing that, I was working on a
What came out of it, if anything?
The calls -- the people were so mean.
People would scream in the phone.
Do you recall any substantive leads coming through the voter hotline that
I've also blacked that out because people are so mean.
I can't speak to how substantial or how credible they were.
Sometimes some old ladies would call that sounded pretty real, but I wouldn't know.
Like finding fraud or anything of the sort?
Did you ever get any feedback of any successes that came out of the
Just make sure he gets the chance to get his question all the
way out, just for the benefit of the court reporter.
So just to be clear, you said that you were not aware of any findings of fraud
that came out of the voter hotline.
And who else staffed the phones for the voter hotline?
I don't know everyone who did it.
It was a lot of our building, but I don't
Now, on November 4th, I'm looking at what appear to be perhaps G chats
you were having with a colleague.
Do you know what I'm talking
So on November 4th at 10:11, you have a line when you say to Kyle -- and
He was an analyst in the war room.
And what was his role as an analyst in the war room?
He would be watching different television shows and clipping things and
I can't specifically speak to what he
Is it fair to say you were friends?
So on what is marked in your production -- we have your whole production
basically marked as exhibit 1, but it is JK121 is the Bates number.
If we count all -- you can see there in the middle there.
"legally cast," end quote, ballots, we believe we will win.
It says, If we count all, quote,
And as to this statement, where are you getting that from?
I think he spoke to us, just kind of a rallying up the troops, to keep working
And Kyle wasn't there for that, so I took notes for him.
So you're basically recounting to Kyle what happened at this rally, basically,
this get the troops going speech?
And then you respond what seems to be your analysis, you say in parens, To
me this sounds like it's going to be a huge legal battle.
Tell me about why you wrote that.
Just because, at the time, we didn't know a lot of information, but there was
a lot of weird things happening with what was getting reported.
So it seemed up to like
the courts to decide, not up to anything else.
When you say a lot of weird things happened, do you mean news reports
And how were you getting your updates about these kind of claims?
Were you getting updates from within the campaign or just from you
We didn't know what was true, what wasn't true at the time.
watching the news and Twitter, et cetera?
Just from watching the news and Twitter.
Now, what was your expectation as far as stay in this job and when you
would be leaving or done with the Trump campaign?
I didn't really know, but I wanted to stay on as long as possible because I
wanted to get paid because I needed to be able to afford housing.
Were you at that time, around election day, looking for a new job?
Because there's a part in one of your chats, which we don't have
to -- it's on JK129, but we don't need to pull it up, where you say -- I think you say
something to the effect of, this honestly takes my mind off trying to find a job.
So is it fair to say around election day, you were looking to work elsewhere?
Did you have expectation that if President Trump had won, you
would've stayed with the campaign and gotten a job elsewhere with the White House or
That was my hope, but I couldn't be sure.
Now, you mentioned that you had the voter fraud line and also researching,
whether dead people voted and who asked you to do that.
So tell us a bit about how you were asked to research into
Zach Parkinson asked us, the research team, to look into if these dead
and then our job was to go try to find the obituaries for these people.
So I don't know where the list of names came from, but we received a list,
So we're going to talk in detail, but when you say that happens in
every election, are you -- is that your way of indicating that you didn't find any evidence
I just was asked to look into dead voters, so
So walk us through your process.
You get a list of names, and then
We would just go on newspapers.com, look for obituaries.
we'd search their names, make sure, like, things matched.
because there's a lot of people with the same first, last names.
but to get, like, locations of where they lived.
I believe we also used -- maybe we used Nexis, not positive,
So you went to newspaper -- so you got a list from Zach Parkinson
that people that he -- is it fair to say that these were individuals that he had reason to
believe could have been dead people who, in fact, voted in the election, and he wanted
the research analysts to go and conduct further analysis to confirm that that was, in fact,
Confirm or deny whether they were alive, yes.
Now, who was asked to do that in conjunction with you?
I don't really remember because it was just two or three of us at a time that
would get taken off the Trump hotline to go and do this project.
So I don't know who all
So was this prior to the November 15th kind of demarcation you mentioned
earlier where a lot of people were let go?
I believe it was before then.
Is there anyone else on your team who you know -- that you recall was
involved in this dead people review?
I know Dean and Matt definitely did.
But I'm not sure about the others.
So you would go to newspapers.com.
Any other sources you used in your efforts to confirm or deny this
Not that I can recall, no.
And what kind of information did Zach Parkinson give you?
I don't remember what's in the spreadsheet, but I think you guys have that
I'll pull that up in a minute.
Now, we've seen in the -- I'm going to kind of switch gears a bit.
In the documents you produced, tell us a bit about where these docs come from,
how you had access to these documents that we got from you.
I was just handed a flash drive with all of the research
And who handed you that flash drive?
And when did he do that?
Are you asking -- are you saying the information that your lawyer produced
to the committee is that flash drive?
It's the information that's specific to
I believe when I started working at the RNC.
I started April 1st, 2021, at the RNC, but I don't know exactly what day I was
So was this flash drive given to you sometime in November 2020?
When was it given to you?
given the flash drive or how many months into work I was given it.
Because we have a lot of -- we have the Joe Biden opposition book on that
And why did Zach Parkinson give you the flash drive?
And currently at the RNC, a lot of my work is similar doing opposition research
So is it fair to say that -- because Zach Parkinson is now the research
So in his role as your supervisor in your current job, he gave you a flash drive
of work product that was done while both of you were working for the Trump campaign.
And you looked at that flash drive and then you pulled information -- or
between you and your lawyer, the information that was responsive to our document
request, and those are the documents that we have.
Did you, yourself, look through the documents you produced to us before
I just looked at the names of them, and I thought if
they were relevant, I just passed them along.
We're going to go through some of those documents.
I want to get a sense of
what you can remember working on yourself versus if you know what other people
worked on, and we can just try to parse that out a bit.
But very broadly, I want to walk through your understanding of how this -- call it
dead voting project, what the conclusion of that project was.
When you were done -- you did your work -- how many names would you say that
you were responsible for versus others?
Was it more in the realm of -- you know, 10 names that you think you looked
And then when you did your research, you provided that to Zach
How would you generally provide your findings to Zach Parkinson?
Sometimes it was in Word documents.
Sometimes it would just be through
And after you provided -- do you recall generally whether you -- your
research -- in your research you concluded that dead people had voted?
We found a few dead voters, yes.
And were you aware of just what you did or were you aware of the
compilation of the research team's efforts as to overall, like, here's what the research
I was just aware of my own efforts.
I wasn't really paying attention to what
So were the memos that we'll look at in a minute that were on this flash
drive, were those memos compilations of everyone's work or did everyone write their
That should be a compilation of everyone's work.
So what was the process by which you all combined your work into a
On Microsoft Word, you can make things into like a SharePoint, where
multiple people can be editing at once.
It's kind of like a live Google doc, but instead it's
So we all just all crashed the document.
Do you recall, after sending this work product up to Zach, do you recall any
feedback coming as to your work, whether either that you were accurate in your findings
I don't remember any feedback whatsoever.
So let's just wrap up about how we -- what you did.
So if you had a name and if you could find an obituary that said John Doe died,
and you -- tell us how many -- what are the number of data points you needed to say I
now feel confident it's the same person?
I'm not sure how many data points, but, typically, in obituaries they'll say like
a spouse or children that are left behind, and then a city or town where they're from,
things like that that match up.
Did you ever use Social Security numbers or have access to that kind of data?
I believe that's on the spreadsheet we were given.
Were you ever told -- were you ever told that any individuals that you had
said were dead voters were not dead voters after further review?
I was not ever given feedback that way, that I recall.
When you were deciding -- when you were researching, did Zach
Parkinson give you parameters of what would be sufficient information to say someone
had, in fact, voted who was dead?
He might have, but I don't remember now.
So here, is this a document that you've seen before?
I'm going to show you what is marked in your production as JK44.
So here when it says confirmed dead voters, is it fair to say that this
is the research team providing this information to Zach Parkinson saying that these are
individuals that have been confirmed to be dead voters?
And so if we scroll down just slightly here -- and I'm just going to kind of walk
through so we see how this works.
is the proof that he's dead, right?
that's claimed to be dead is, in fact, dead, and you do that by looking at obituaries,
And then if we scroll to the bottom of this page, it says, Blalock is registered
Meaning, would someone else have done it for you if you -- for someone, or
that you just know that that is not your research work then?
So I never had a login to GOP data center when I worked on the campaign,
so that wouldn't have been me.
That's the first thing you try to find is that this person
Were you all given directives as to look into someone's political affiliation for the
I just know it wasn't me.
It might have been another researcher who had a
But I never had a login, so I don't know.
So if we scroll to the next page here, it then has his voter info and
these seem just to be noting the person has passed away, not that they voted.
as an unaffiliated voter according to GOP data center.
It's saying here that you found this individual.
So just to understand how to read these, it looks like
Were you all relying on whether they had voted to come from Zach Parkinson, or
how were you noting that this was the same person?
I didn't do that part, so I don't know.
So if you could, if you could walk us through more detail.
look in this confirmed section as a compilation of proof of death, and I'm trying to get a

person was, in fact, a dead voter?
I can only speak to the obituaries and if it matched up with the name.
was kind of my only role there.
So you're given a name by Zach Parkinson, and is your job basically

And when you say the other information -- and we can pull up one of these
look at this in a minute.
I can show this to you in a minute, but I'm going to read to you -- we'll

So is that the kind of information you would look at from Zach
Yes, but I didn't have access to GOP data center, so I couldn't see the voter

see it from, like, the one side.
know how it all matches up.
So I only did half the project, so I don't -- I also don't
So who did the other half of the project?
To be clear, what you did was confirmed the person had died.
or not they were the same person who had voted, how would you do that?
So -- sorry, I didn't mean to interrupt you.
So we were given that spreadsheet with the information such as the date of birth
and their name, and I believe maybe a Social Security number there, and then you can
pull that information up on Nexis and you can get more information about the person
from there, such as their spouses, children, and then places they've lived, things like that.
And then, with that information, if that matched up to the obituary, making sure it was
the same person as that person that was provided on the spreadsheet with that Social
Security number and date of birth.
So I was more so matching up the obituaries with
And tell me if I'm missing something, but in deciding whether
someone's a dead voter, it seems like you have to find out three things:
did someone, in fact, die, is there truly a dead person out there somewhere; and the third
thing is like, is the person in point one who voted, that information at least, is that the
same information and match of the same person who died, and that's how you'd be able
to confirm and deny whether there was a dead voter.
Because there's got to be a vote for it to be voter fraud;
So here, it sounds like -- first of all, is that fair to say, like, the whole entire
process, that would be how one would confirm whether there was a dead voter?
And then for your process, you were confirming, it sounds like, whether this
person -- there's, in fact, a dead person, hence the benefit of having an obituary -- that
people write obituaries of people who have, in fact, died.
Now, how did the other process happen?
proving of that death -- one, that someone, in fact, voted, that point one I made, and

I believe that we matched up the person's name next -- Social Security

that's as far as I know those two things got matched up.
because I'm not aware of anything else there.
I can't speak to it any further

I'm trying to get a sense of how you're

you're asking her -- at least if I understand the question, you can tell me if I'm wrong.
think she's saying she doesn't know on that side, unless I misunderstood your question.
So I understood her to say she only

Zach Parkinson sends you a list of dead people they think voted.
So is it right that you were only doing the proof of death, or were you doing
That's what I'm trying to clarify.
So you prove someone -- Alex -- excuse me.
find the obituary, you confirm this person looks dead, date of birth matches, whatever,
Whether -- who do you pass the information to?
So we put it in a SharePoint, and then our deputy, Dean Cleary, I believe, he

But here's what I'm not understanding.
Can't speak to that for sure.
someone as dead doesn't seem to move the ball too far forward as to confirming whether
what involvement you had or who else would have been involved in finding that missing
So it seems like there's a piece missing.
Because if you have an obituary match a name on a spreadsheet, as I understand

But the point is to say, did that
person in fact -- is that the same person who voted?
So here, for example -- and we can

So what I'm trying to understand is that, if you didn't do that, then who did do
Or if you did that, how did you do it?
I did not do that, and I don't know who did that.
So when you would -- for example, when you found matches, is it fair to say
that you then were not confirming that someone was a dead voter; you were confirming
I -- when I was given the spreadsheet, I just assumed they were a voter, that
But I don't know for sure where that spreadsheet came from, so I
In your analysis, you presumed that the people who were on that list had, in fact,

While that's coming up, do you recall in this exercise that there were dead people
